webTitle: How Alice Nutter went from Chumbawamba to prestige TV

fields.headline: How Alice Nutter went from Chumbawamba to prestige TV
fields.standfirst: She spent two decades in the anarchist band who drenched John Prescott at the Brits. Now she’s writing big-budget shows starring Hilary Swank
fields.trailText: She spent two decades in the anarchist band who drenched John Prescott at the Brits. Now she’s writing big-budget shows starring Hilary Swank
fields.body:
The scruffy camper van in the drive looks promising. Apart from that though, there’s little to suggest that this handsome former vicarage on a sleepy cul-de-sac in a working-class area of Leeds is home to an anarchist. One who once, along with some of her bandmates, very publicly poured a bucket of icy water over the deputy prime minister’s head. There’s even a festive wreath hanging on the front door – that’s practically bourgeois isn’t it?

To be honest I’ve been doubting Alice Nutter’s continued anarcho-punk credentials since speaking to her on the phone, when she tipped me off that for an extra £20 I could upgrade to first class on the train. First class?! What, so I can attack the enemy from the inside? No, because it’s easier to get some work done …

“Everyone thinks that somehow we’d be preserved in aspic, you know, like aged anarchists,” she says after letting me in. “I think everybody should have the right to first class, I don’t think some people should have it and some people shouldn’t. I think everybody should have the right to what’s good in life – I’m not embarrassed about that.”

Alice Nutter offers me a latte. A FRIGGING LATTE! (He drinks a whiskey drink, he drinks a latte drink.) Her 19-year-old daughter, Mae, comes into the kitchen to make toast. She knows “embarrassingly little” about Chumbawamba, or Tubthumping. “I’ve always known mum as a writer,” she says. Because that’s what Alice Nutter is now. A writer of plays, and a TV screenwriter, most recently on Trust, the entertaining drama series about the kidnapping of Jean Paul Getty III.

Alice always knew she was going to be a writer, ever since a teacher told her mum and dad that their daughter had an extraordinary command of the English language. But Nutter (or Anne Holden as she was before she punked herself up by deed poll, taking the name of a woman who was hanged in 1612 for witchcraft) didn’t get off to the brightest of starts. Born to a working-class family in Burnley, she had a bad relationship with her dad, got involved with drugs and left school with only a couple of O levels. Fortunately, she started hanging around with a more aspirational group of kids and that basically saved her. Together they became Chumbawamba. (I get knocked down, but I get up again.)

Alice, now 57, was with the band for 22 of their 30 years in existence, singing, playing percussion, jumping around. “I’m not particularly musical,” she admits. “I’m a good dancer and I’m theatrical, I could get away with it.”

For 20 years they lived in a squat in Leeds, sharing (very little) money, and ideas, becoming vegans (long before everyone became a vegan), getting involved with political causes – South Africa, Northern Ireland, the miners’ strike. More than anything, they were friends. Still are.

Were they anarchists? “I don’t think it matters what you call yourself. What you need to do is align yourself with what’s most useful for change.” She says inequality was their main beef: “You can bring everything down to inequality and injustice. And it can be about class, or race, or whatever. At the time we were really anti-parliamentary because we thought they were all the same.”

These days Alice knocks on doors for the Labour party, for Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell. “Promoting co-ops and cooperation, saying they’ll pledge £100m a year to help the homeless, I’ll knock on doors for that,” she says. “I was lucky, I came up through the postwar settlement, I screwed my education up, but I had those opportunities.”

She feels that working-class kids today don’t have the chances she had. “I’d never be where I am today without the dole. That paid for me to have a creative life.”

She describes herself as “a sort of communist-Marxist. Not a party political Communist, but in the sense of all things in common for people and the idea of sharing. I know I’ve got a lot but I’m totally willing to have less.” There’s a bust of Karl Marx on the mantelpiece, along with one of James Dean. We’ve moved into the cosy living room, with a wood-burner, a Christmas tree and biscuits.

Chumbawamba’s big hit, Tubthumping, an anthem of defiance for the ordinary and the oppressed, came out in 1997. It didn’t win anything at the Brit awards ceremony, but that was where John Prescott got his soaking. Chumbawamba were angry about the government’s failure to resolve the Liverpool dockers’ strike. (They were not fans of New Labour or Blair.) They were also drunk, and disappointed – not so much about their own failure to win but about the fact that winning would have given a platform to the sacked scouse docker they’d brought along.

Tubthumping also, for the first time, provided Chumbawamba with a bit of money. Ironic perhaps, but equally shared. Alice left the band in 2004, because “if you’re jumping about in your mid-40s, you look fucking stupid”. And because she knew she wasn’t really a musician, she was a writer. “I’d been planning it, in my head, all my life.”

At the age of 28, while in Chumbawamba, Alice took an English A level. Plus she’d written short stories, a play for a Bradford anarchist group, and – with the band – a pantomime for the kids of striking miners in south Wales. “We didn’t know owt about theatre, we were making it up as we went along. We’d heard of Brecht, didn’t know fucking anything about it. I’d only been to the theatre twice before I started writing for it. I saw Hamlet and I thought, I can do that.”

It wasn’t as easy as that. She soon realised that though she might have the right muscles she didn’t have the craft, and sitting at home trying wasn’t working. There needed to be a plan, focus. It was going to take time and a lot of graft. She started a screenwriting MA but quit when she began to feel it was more about getting a qualification than learning to write.

Then she got on a so-you-want-to-be-a-writer course at the West Yorkshire Playhouse, which meant cancelling a holiday. That led to the offer of a three-week run in the Playhouse courtyard of her play Foxes, about a group of asylum seekers in Leeds. “I had a budget for a ladder and bucket, but there were actors, and I was so unbelievably thrilled.”

Then came another course, this time with Jimmy McGovern, after which he asked if she would like to pitch to write an episode of The Street. She got it, and would have written more episodes if breast cancer had not got in the way. “A hiccup,” she says.

Through another project she met Simon Beaufoy (“Boofoo, Bow Fort, Bow Fowey … I still can’t say his name”), who wrote The Full Monty and Slumdog Millionaire. He wasn’t immediately overjoyed by his writing partner for this project, which was about undercover cops. “He said to them, ‘Whatever you do, don’t get an activist, get a writer,’” says Nutter. “And they got me, and he said, ‘They got a fucking activist.’ But then I handed the script in and he realised I was a writer.”

That one didn’t work out, but the pair realised they saw eye to eye. So when he created Trust, the big-budget TV series for FX directed by Danny Boyle (Oh Danny Boyle, Danny Boyle, Danny Boyle) among others, he hired Nutter – first to write one episode, then another, then to be involved in the whole thing.Trust rigorously explores money, family and power structures. And not just regarding the dysfunctional Gettys, but also the Italian kidnappers. Is the subject matter, the super rich, surprising for a Tubthumping anarchist to be involved with? No, she says, because it’s full of political themes. “And if you look at really rich people, there’s a socialism in the rich, they share everything with each other. It’s just no one else gets it.”

It was also the most fun Nutter has ever had at work. “I just kept thinking: I can’t believe my luck.” Now she’s working on another series with Beaufoy – about happiness.

Two decades of Chumbawamba was, she says, the perfect training for being a screenwriter. “Because it’s collaborative. And because people clapping [what you do] for 20 years gives you a lot of confidence. I realised I had the rigour to start something and finish it.”

It’s time for photos. Where does the photographer want her? Somewhere that looks bourgeois, like the flash kitchen, I suggest. “You’re obsessed,” she says. She would give me a lift to the station, but her car has a puncture. Is there an Uber service in Leeds, I wonder? Yes, but she doesn’t use them, on principle. “Once they’ve got the prices down they drive everyone else out.” She calls a local cab company instead. Credentials, credibility, dignity – all remain intact.

Alice, now 57, was with the band for 22 of their 30 years in existence, singing, playing percussion, jumping around. “I’m not particularly musical,” she admits. “I’m a good dancer and I’m theatrical, I could get away with it.” For 20 years they lived in a squat in Leeds, sharing (very little) money, and ideas, becoming vegans (long before everyone became a vegan), getting involved with political causes – South Africa, Northern Ireland, the miners’ strike. More than anything, they were friends. Still are. Were they anarchists? “I don’t think it matters what you call yourself. What you need to do is align yourself with what’s most useful for change.” She says inequality was their main beef: “You can bring everything down to inequality and injustice. And it can be about class, or race, or whatever. At the time we were really anti-parliamentary because we thought they were all the same.” These days Alice knocks on doors for the Labour party, for Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell. “Promoting co-ops and cooperation, saying they’ll pledge £100m a year to help the homeless, I’ll knock on doors for that,” she says. “I was lucky, I came up through the postwar settlement, I screwed my education up, but I had those opportunities.” She feels that working-class kids today don’t have the chances she had. “I’d never be where I am today without the dole. That paid for me to have a creative life.” She describes herself as “a sort of communist-Marxist. Not a party political Communist, but in the sense of all things in common for people and the idea of sharing. I know I’ve got a lot but I’m totally willing to have less.” There’s a bust of Karl Marx on the mantelpiece, along with one of James Dean. We’ve moved into the cosy living room, with a wood-burner, a Christmas tree and biscuits. Chumbawamba’s big hit, Tubthumping, an anthem of defiance for the ordinary and the oppressed, came out in 1997. It didn’t win anything at the Brit awards ceremony, but that was where John Prescott got his soaking. Chumbawamba were angry about the government’s failure to resolve the Liverpool dockers’ strike. (They were not fans of New Labour or Blair.) They were also drunk, and disappointed – not so much about their own failure to win but about the fact that winning would have given a platform to the sacked scouse docker they’d brought along. Tubthumping also, for the first time, provided Chumbawamba with a bit of money. Ironic perhaps, but equally shared. Alice left the band in 2004, because “if you’re jumping about in your mid-40s, you look fucking stupid”. And because she knew she wasn’t really a musician, she was a writer. “I’d been planning it, in my head, all my life.” At the age of 28, while in Chumbawamba, Alice took an English A level. Plus she’d written short stories, a play for a Bradford anarchist group, and – with the band – a pantomime for the kids of striking miners in south Wales. “We didn’t know owt about theatre, we were making it up as we went along. We’d heard of Brecht, didn’t know fucking anything about it. I’d only been to the theatre twice before I started writing for it. I saw Hamlet and I thought, I can do that.” It wasn’t as easy as that. She soon realised that though she might have the right muscles she didn’t have the craft, and sitting at home trying wasn’t working. There needed to be a plan, focus. It was going to take time and a lot of graft. She started a screenwriting MA but quit when she began to feel it was more about getting a qualification than learning to write. Then she got on a so-you-want-to-be-a-writer course at the West Yorkshire Playhouse, which meant cancelling a holiday. That led to the offer of a three-week run in the Playhouse courtyard of her play Foxes, about a group of asylum seekers in Leeds. “I had a budget for a ladder and bucket, but there were actors, and I was so unbelievably thrilled.” Then came another course, this time with Jimmy McGovern, after which he asked if she would like to pitch to write an episode of The Street. She got it, and would have written more episodes if breast cancer had not got in the way. “A hiccup,” she says. Through another project she met Simon Beaufoy (“Boofoo, Bow Fort, Bow Fowey … I still can’t say his name”), who wrote The Full Monty and Slumdog Millionaire. He wasn’t immediately overjoyed by his writing partner for this project, which was about undercover cops. “He said to them, ‘Whatever you do, don’t get an activist, get a writer,’” says Nutter. “And they got me, and he said, ‘They got a fucking activist.’ But then I handed the script in and he realised I was a writer.” That one didn’t work out, but the pair realised they saw eye to eye. So when he created Trust, the big-budget TV series for FX directed by Danny Boyle (Oh Danny Boyle, Danny Boyle, Danny Boyle) among others, he hired Nutter – first to write one episode, then another, then to be involved in the whole thing.Trust rigorously explores money, family and power structures. And not just regarding the dysfunctional Gettys, but also the Italian kidnappers. Is the subject matter, the super rich, surprising for a Tubthumping anarchist to be involved with? No, she says, because it’s full of political themes. “And if you look at really rich people, there’s a socialism in the rich, they share everything with each other. It’s just no one else gets it.” It was also the most fun Nutter has ever had at work. “I just kept thinking: I can’t believe my luck.” Now she’s working on another series with Beaufoy – about happiness. Two decades of Chumbawamba was, she says, the perfect training for being a screenwriter. “Because it’s collaborative. And because people clapping [what you do] for 20 years gives you a lot of confidence. I realised I had the rigour to start something and finish it.” It’s time for photos. Where does the photographer want her? Somewhere that looks bourgeois, like the flash kitchen, I suggest. “You’re obsessed,” she says. She would give me a lift to the station, but her car has a puncture. Is there an Uber service in Leeds, I wonder? Yes, but she doesn’t use them, on principle. “Once they’ve got the prices down they drive everyone else out.” She calls a local cab company instead. Credentials, credibility, dignity – all remain intact.

webTitle: Australian Open: Andy Murray beaten by Roberto Bautista Agut in five sets – as it happened

fields.headline: Australian Open: Andy Murray beaten by Roberto Bautista Agut in five sets – as it happened
fields.standfirst:
Andy Murray lost in the first round in Melbourne but produced a tremendous fight in what could turn out to the final match of his career

  • Report: Valiant Murray goes the distance with Bautista Agut
fields.trailText: Game-by-game report: Andy Murray lost in the first round in Melbourne but produced a tremendous fight in what could turn out to the final match of his career
fields.body:
12.30pm GMT

Anyway, that’s all from me. We’ve been treated to an Andy Murray classic, a see-sawing five-setter which has been utterly draining to watch. If this was his final match, he’s bowed out in style. It ended in defeat to Roberto Bautista Agut, but this was the ultimate moral victory for Murray. Thanks for reading and emailing. Bye.

12.28pm GMT

You’ll probably want to know that Roger Federer has beaten Denis Istomin in straight sets, while Bernard Tomic is out after losing to Marin Cilic. Rafael Nadal also sailed through after beating Australia’s James Duckworth. Caroline Wozniacki, the defending women’s champion, is also through to the second round.

Related: Katie Boulter soars into second round despite forgetting new tie-break rules

Related: Ashleigh Barty up and running at Australian Open with straight sets win

Related: Kyle Edmund crashes out of Australian Open but Dan Evans goes through

Updated at 12.30pm GMT

12.18pm GMT

That’s all from Andy Murray. Now he gets to drag himself off for an ice bath. You know, it’s probably for the best he doesn’t have to play on Wednesday. He looked in agony by the end. Four hours and nine minutes that took. What now? The likelihood is that was Murray’s final match. He’s hinting at having an operation to deal with his chronic right hip. He’d love to play one more match at Wimbledon, which would be a fitting venue for his farewell. But how much more can he take?

Updated at 12.21pm GMT

12.16pm GMT

More from Murray! “I’ve been very fortunate in mny ways - and unlucky, I guess - to compete in an era with the guys around. Roger, Novak, Rafa, I have great respect for them. I’ve had some great battles. To have the respect of your peers is very important.”

12.15pm GMT

Now we’ve heard from Andy Murray, he gets to look up the big screen, where they’re showing a montage of tributes from his colleagues. “You’ve done Scotland proud, you’ve done Britain proud, you’re a sir - who can say that?”Roger Federer says. Over to Novak Djokovic, who remembers the time Murray “kicked my butt” at Wimbledon in 2013. “Thank you always for leaving your heart and every last drop of energy on the court,” the world No1 adds. “Judy raised such a fine young gentleman,” Sloane Stephens says. Caroline Wozniacki says she can coach him. “Take care, buddy,” Federer says. “Thank you, my friend,” Djokovic adds. “All the best.”

12.13pm GMT

Andy Murray, his voice wobbling and his bottom lip trembling, speaks! “Amazing. I think I’m going to be all right. Thank you so much to everyone who came out tonight. I’ve loved playing here over the years. If this was the last match it was an amazing way to end. I gave literally everything I had. It wasn’t enough tonight, so congratulations to Roberto and his team. I don’t really have anything else to say. Thanks to everyone. My team, my family, everyone who helped me down the years. Maybe I’ll see you again. I’ll do everything possible to try. If I want to go again I need to have a big operation which there’s no guarantee I’ll come back from but I’ll give it my best shot.

12.09pm GMT

Roberto Bautista Agut, who plays Australia’s John Millman next, speaks! “Today was incredible. Andy deserves this atmosphere. Andy deserves all the people who came to watch him. It was an unbelievable match. He is a tough fighter. He gave everything he had until the last point and I want to congratulate him for everything he did for tennis.”

Updated at 12.09pm GMT

12.07pm GMT

Related: Andy Murray out of Australian Open after losing what could be his last match

12.07pm GMT

Andy Murray’s off his chair to accept the crowd’s acclaim. Nobody’s going anywhere. Judy’s managing to smile as she watches her brilliant son.

Updated at 12.24pm GMT

12.06pm GMT

Roberto Bautista Agut beats Andy Murray 6-4, 6-4, 6-7, 6-7, 6-2!

This, then, could be the final game of Sir Andy Murray’s career. Here we are. We don’t want to be here. But here we are. It’s been one hell of a ride, but the finishing line is hovering into view, with Bautista Agut quick to establish a 30-0 lead. Murray being Murray, he continues to scramble, drawing on those unrivalled retrieval skills, but it’s not enough any more. Bautista Agut softens up his prey before earning three match points with a smash. He wallops a forehand down the line. Murray gets a racket to it - of course he does - but it’s not going over the net. It’s over. Bautista Agut roars and the pair embrace at the net. There were two winners out there today.

Updated at 12.15pm GMT

12.02pm GMT

Fifth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 2-5 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): After four hours of sweat, huge applause greets Murray as he steps up to serve. He looks like he has something in his eye. They’re a little red. Judy looks emotional. Murray holds his racket high to signal his appreciation for a tremendous ovation. Then he gets down to business, winning the first point. The camera pans back to Judy, who’s just about managing to hold it together. Just. Murray, determined not to let the moment pass, nails an ace for 30-15. Back to Judy. Frowning. Jamie Murray, Andy’s big brother, also looks fretful. Bautista Agut wins the next point thanks to a lucky net cord. Then a huge return from the Spaniard causes Murray to net a tired forehand. It’s the first match point. Murray being Murray, though, he keeps running, keeps hustling, keeps pouring his soul into all he does, and he saves it with a brilliant volley. Judy’s smiling now. Somehow Murray holds, serving superbly. One more clenched fist. A small victory for Murray but it looks like it means the world to him. Bautista Agut will serve for it. He’s going to win this match, surely, but he hasn’t managed to crush Murray’s spirit.

Updated at 12.12pm GMT

11.55am GMT

Fifth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-5 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut holds to love. He’s a game from victory. Murray will serve to stay in it. It is likely to be his last ever service game at the Australian Open, a tournament he love so much.

11.52am GMT

Fifth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Fuel’s leaking all over the place now. From 30-0, Murray dips again and Bautista Agut fights back to earn a break point. Murray nets a backhand. He looks cooked. There’s surely no way back now.

Updated at 11.55am GMT

11.48am GMT

Fifth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-3 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): A love hold consolidates the break for Bautista Agut. Are we witnessing the end for Murray? Or is there another twist on the way?

Updated at 11.48am GMT

11.45am GMT

Fifth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-2 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): It’s worth remembering that this will go to a champion’s tie-break if it goes to 6-6; it would be first to 10 points in that scenario. But it might not get that far. At 15-30, Murray makes a couple of questionable choices. A drop shot isn’t good enough and a hopeful lob’s gobbled up by Bautista Agut, who finds himself with two break points. Murray saves the first with a polished smash, but he cracks on the second, a driven forehand down the line from Bautista Agut enough to break through. Murray needs more heroics now. But has he got anything left in the tank?

11.39am GMT

Fifth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): This is Murray at his best. Bautista Agut drop shots. Murray’s there. Bautista Agut lobs. Murray scampers back and manages to scoop the ball over his head and into the air. They rally and Bautista Agut ends up knocking a backhand wide. Murray, exhausted, holds a fist aloft. This is wonderful theatre and Murray, with the bit between his teeth, can smell blood in the water. He drop shots now and Bautista Agut sends a ragged forehand wide. This is threatening to get away from the Spaniard - but he manages to fight back to 30-all. Murray’s level drops and Bautista Agut holds to 30.

11.35am GMT

Fifth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-0 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): This could be the final set of Andy Murray’s career. Or it could be one of the most memorable he’s ever played. Either way, it’s extraordinary he’s managed to keep the argument going this long. You’re almost tempted to make him the favourite now. Bautista Agut’s been driven to distraction by his brilliantly stubborn opponent, who opens by holding to 15 amid an increasingly boisterous atmosphere.

11.30am GMT

Andy Murray wins the fourth set 7-6 to force a fifth set!

Fourth set tie-break: Murray* 7-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray slices a serve to the forehand and Bautista Agut nets a sliced return! “Yeeeeeeeeeeeeeaaaaarrrggghhhhhh!” Murray cries. He’s forced a fifth set! Can you believe it? No. But also yes. Because it’s Andy Murray, so the illogical makes sense.

Updated at 11.53am GMT

11.28am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray* 6-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray nets a backhand. It’s edgy now. Three set points have come and gone.

11.27am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray 6-3 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Stout volleying from Bautista Agut keeps this alive.

11.26am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray 6-2 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Murray nets a slice. One down.

11.26am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray* 6-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray earns five set points after leaving Bautista Agut stranded with a drop shot.

11.24am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray* 5-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): A magnificent volley from Murray reminds you why he was No1 in the world two years ago. Don’t retire!

11.24am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray 4-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut’s in danger of falling apart here. He knocks a backhand long. Murray’s in charge now.

11.23am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray 3-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut nets a forehand!

11.22am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray* 2-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Bautista Agut sends a return long. Murray is so pumped up.

11.21am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray* 1-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray knocks a poor backhand long. “No!” he cries. Bad miss.

11.21am GMT

Fourth set tie-break: Murray 1-0 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Murray hits ferociously and accurately and Bautista Agut ends up wafting a forehand long.

11.19am GMT

Fourth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 6-6 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray has to wait before serving here, because they’re letting off fireworks at the MCG. Once the distant noise fades away, they get going again. Murray makes it 15-0 and then he volleys superbly for 30-0. He’s serving so well. He holds to love. Another tie-break!

Updated at 11.53am GMT

11.16am GMT

Fourth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 5-6 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): “Make that ball,” Murray shouts after missing a forehand for 15-0. He’s struggling to make an impact in Bautista Agut’s service games. The Spaniard holds with minimal fuss.

11.12am GMT

Fourth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 5-5 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray holds to love. He mooches back to the court, his shoulders sagging, his gait weary, and asks for a towel. It’s amazing he’s still going.

11.08am GMT

Fourth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 4-5 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Professionalism’s required from Bautista Agut, plus a bit of inspiration of the kind that flares when he raps a superb passing shot past Murray for 30-0. He does it again moments later, making Murray shake his head in frustration. Another hold for Bautista Agut, who’s a game from victory.

11.05am GMT

Fourth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 4-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray’s service games are where much of the intrigue lies. While Bautista Agut’s holding easily, it’s more of a struggle for Murray to keep going. He must be knackered. But one way to keep fatigue at bay is to keep making serves; you never know, maybe he’s going to stave off retirement by becoming a power server in the Anderson or Isner mould. He holds to 15. Bautista Agut, who’s getting absolutely no support from the crowd, must be wondering when this guy’s going to fold. He’s not alone.

Updated at 11.25am GMT

11.01am GMT

Fourth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 3-4 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut makes a statement with a love hold.

Updated at 11.01am GMT

10.56am GMT

Fourth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 3-3 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): All of a sudden, it’s 0-30. Another sniff of a chance for Bautista Agut. Murray needs all his grit now. He also needs a bit of luck. A drop shot at 15-30’s begging for punishment, only for Bautista Agut to whip a forehand wide. Another dink from Bautista Agut goes wide, making it 40-30, and Murray serves well to hold. Grit levels: still high.

10.52am GMT

Fourth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 2-3 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Serving well, Bautista Agut holds without ceremony. “I’m currently in work, so not able to actually watch the match,” Matt Dony says. “Reading your reports of the various things Murray is shouting at himself has reminded me of my all time favourite Andy Murray on-court quote. From the French Open, 5 or 6 years ago, a plaintive cry of ‘I’m trying my tits off out here!’ Magnificent work from a magnificent tennis player.”

10.48am GMT

Fourth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 2-2 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): In other news, Roger Federer took half an hour to win the first set against Denis Istomin. For once, though, Federer isn’t the biggest story. Two years after the Swiss’s incredible comeback at this tournament, it’s another hall-of-famer who’s grabbing the limelight, with Murray still plugging away and doing his best to gulp in as much as oxygen as possible between points. He quickly moves to 40-0. He looks in control. Appearances, as we’ve seen today, can be deceiving. Bautista Agut creeps back into the game and Murray double-faults at 40-30, letting it go to deuce. A little slump’s created an opening. Somehow, though, Murray manages to keep the door shut.

Updated at 11.04am GMT

10.43am GMT

Fourth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 1-2 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): “Dammit, Andy, why aren’t you coming in there?” Murray says after netting a backhand at 30-all. Just another one of those conversations he likes to have with himself in public. The stoical Bautista Agut looks at his eccentric opponent quizzically and goes on to hold with more unfussy tennis.

“Following the match from Zurich, where the normally excellent Swiss national broadcaster is disappointingly showing Roger Federer’s match instead of Murray’s,” James Ferguson says. “Fortunately, no one was in my office to hear my yelp of excitement and pride when Andy grabbed the third set! Could a big Scottish heart be enough for a bit more magic? If Andy wins this match, I’ll give up Swiss chocolate for the rest of 2019.”

Updated at 10.43am GMT

10.39am GMT

Fourth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 1-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray loses the first point. He wins the next four. Just give him the title now. He’s earned it.

10.37am GMT

Fourth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 0-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut gets back to work, holding comfortably. As dramatic as the end of the third set was, it’s still hard to see Murray pulling this off. He surely doesn’t have the stamina for it.

10.32am GMT

Andy Murray wins the third set; Roberto Bautista Agut leads 6-4, 6-4, 6-7!

Third set tie-break: Murray 7-5 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Murray serves out wide. Bautista Agut lofts his return into the air and Murray, limping and looking like he’s run seven marathons over the weekend, shows him how to hit a drive volley! Ha. There is in no limit to his depths of absurdity. Into a fourth we go!

Updated at 10.37am GMT

10.30am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray 6-5 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut wipes out the first with a drop shot. It’s Murray to serve,

10.30am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray 6-4 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Incredible! Murray makes Bautista Agut play one more shot and the Spaniard loses his nerve, smashing an easy drive volley way long! Murray has two set points!

10.29am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray* 5-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Bautista Agut wipes out the mini-break, running round a forehand to pick Murray off down the line.

10.28am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray* 5-3 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Or not. Murray produces another ace, his 14th so far. Bautista Agut challenges to no avail.

10.27am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray 4-3 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Murray’s doubled over again when Bautista Agut polishes off a grinding rally with a drop shot. He might be running out of juice.

10.26am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray 4-2 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Murray challenges a Bautista Agut serve. It clipped the line. Murray has one challenge left.

10.25am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray* 4-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Bautista Agut sends a forehand long at the end of a tense rally. Murray’s doubled over at the end of it, wheezing away.

10.24am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray* 3-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray sends an ace out wide.

10.23am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray 2-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut sends an ace down the middle.

10.23am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray 2-0 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): The first mini-break goes to Murray, a clever slice doing the trick.

10.22am GMT

Third set tie-break: Murray* 1-0 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray takes the first point.

10.21am GMT

Third set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 6-6 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Murray returns brilliantly to make it 0-15. Bautista Agut, annoyed with the way this is heading, smacks a brutal forehand away for 15-all. Another one makes it 30-15. The Spaniard holds. Tie-break. How much does Murray have left?

10.17am GMT

Third set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 6-5 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray, refusing to go quietly, slams a couple of aces away to hold again. He’s earned himself a tie-break at the very least.

10.14am GMT

Third set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 5-5 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Out of nowhere, in a totally weird turnaround, Bautista Agut’s serving to stay in the set. Against, remember, a man who’s going to retire soon. At 15-0, Murray wins another mini-duel. More fist pumping. The fans are loving this. “You can do it, Andy!” someone shouts. The game goes to 30-all. Bautista Agut manages to dig out a volley for 40-30. Murray forces deuce. He hops a bit, because he’s absurd, and he has a break point when Bautista Agut knocks a forehand wide. Bautista Agut nets a first serve. Then a serve down the middle’s called out, only for the umpire to correct the call. Biting his hand, Murray challenges to no avail and Bautista Agut gets his first serve back. On they go. A long rally ensues. The tension builds. It’s classic Murray, but he can’t make the breakthrough and nets a forehand. Judy nods, smiles kindly and says “Come on.” Mum knows best. Yet Bautista Agut holds on. “One last time, Jacob,” Simon McMahon says. “COME ON ANDY!!!!!”

Updated at 10.22am GMT

10.06am GMT

Third set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 5-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): The first two points are shared. Bautista Agut wants to get this done. With Murray rooted to the spot, the Spaniard drives a backhand down the line for 15-30. This is a tight battle at the moment, though, and Murray serves well for 30-all. He’s digging deep. He nets a forehand, handing over a break point, but he saves it with a stunning backhand for deuce. An ace raises his spirits. Another one has him leaping into the air, letting it all hang loose, emotion pouring out of him as he roars and shakes his fists. It’s like he’s just won Wimbledon! This is how much it means to him. Murray just will not give up. He doesn’t know how to give up. It isn’t in his DNA.

Updated at 10.08am GMT

9.59am GMT

Third set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 4-4 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut holds easily. “Whenever I have watched tennis, most of my attention has been on the likes of Federer and Nadal,” Abhijato Sensarma says. “Yet, without realising it, I have always cared to check his progress through a tournament whenever I get the opportunity. He has not been a “favourite” for many because of the even more dominant legends he has played it. Yet, he always remained in the back of the mind of everybody. There is something quite inexplicably beautiful about his game when he is in form.

“His first Wimbledon win was perhaps his greatest achievement and he deserved every bit of it, along with all the other accolades which he has won in his life. The game is seemingly slipping away now. It is painful to watch for even the most causal of viewers once you knew the emotional context dominating this match. Perhaps, he has told himself to enjoy what might be his last professional match - and we must egg him on. We shall hope for one last miracle match from him, yet know he has done enough to not ask anymore from him. No matter what happens today, live on, Mr Murray!”

9.55am GMT

Third set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 4-3 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray holds to 15, slicing an ace out wide to keep this going. Are you totally sure you want to bet against him?!

9.54am GMT

Third set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 3-3 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut restores some order, holding comfortably. Elsewhere defending women’s champion Caroline Wozniacki has beaten Alyson van Uytvanck on Rod Laver Arena, where they await the arrival of Roger Federer and Denis Istomin.

9.50am GMT

Third set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 3-2 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): “Let’s go!” Murray yelps as he moves into a 40-0 lead. If this is the end, he’s decided he might as well go out fighting. He might as well swing a bit, land a few blows, have some fun, give a supportive crowd something to remember him by. He holds with an ace, the cue for more whooping in the stands, and returns to his chair for a well-earned rest.

9.48am GMT

Third set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 2-2 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Out of nowhere, Murray clambers back from 30-0 to win three straight points and earn a break point! Roared on by the crowd, the wounded hero takes his chance by surprising Bautista Agut with a drop shot. Bautista Agut replies with a dink, but the space is there for Murray to prod a backhand down the line and break for the first time! You’ve got to love him. Murray’s whipping up the crowd and Judy’s on her feet, a big smile on her face as she applauds her ridiculous son. How does he find the will?



Updated at 10.06am GMT

9.42am GMT

Third set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 1-2 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): A drop shot from Bautista Agut draws Murray forward, enabling the Spaniard to send a forehand past his stranded opponent for 0-15. Murray’s increasingly desperate. Soon it’s 0-30. The error’s are stacking up. Murray tries a drop shot, but Bautista Agut’s too quick and he earns three break points with a granite volley. Murray’s serve crumbles again. There’s a whiff of tragedy about this now. As hard as Murray’s trying, there’s little enjoyment to be found in seeing a champion struggle this way.

Updated at 9.59am GMT

9.36am GMT

Third set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 1-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): A routine love hold for Bautista Agut, who doesn’t look likely to throw this away.

Updated at 9.37am GMT

9.33am GMT

Third set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 1-0 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray has come back from two sets down on nine occasions. This would be a good time to round it up to 10, wouldn’t it? He starts this set with a deft volley. He responds to an incredible lob from Bautista Agut for 15-all by moving to 40-30. He holds when the Spaniard sends a forehand wide. It’s on!

9.28am GMT

Roberto Bautista Agut wins the second set; he leads 6-4, 6-4!

A skidding forehand from Bautista Agut makes it 15-0. Soon it’s 30-0. It’s all a bit tragic. Bautista Agut doesn’t do anything special, but he doesn’t really need to be inspired to beat a man who’s basically playing on one leg. That hobbling opponent does have a lot of heart, though, and he somehow drags himself back to 30-all. Yet Bautista Agut quickly earns a set point and converts it by whacking a serve past Murray, who’s heading for a first-round exit.

Updated at 9.32am GMT

9.21am GMT

Second set: Murray* 4-6, 4-5 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Serving to stay in the set, Murray makes himself feel better with a feathery drop shot for 30-15. Another powerful serve makes it 40-15. He holds.

9.20am GMT

Second set: Murray 4-6, 3-5 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut continues to give nothing away on serve. Murray will serve to stay in the set.

9.17am GMT

Second set: Murray* 4-6, 3-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Ignoring the rising pain and fatigue rippling through his battered body, Murray somehow summons the will to go from 0-15 to 40-15, a lovely backhand down the line a reminder of better times. In the stands, his mum looks concerned for her boy. But Judy will be pleased to see him celebrate holding to 30. If nothing else, Murray can be pleased with himself for refusing to roll over out there. He’s clearly outmatched, but his effort is setting an example for others to follow.

9.12am GMT

Second set: Murray 4-6, 2-4 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): While I’m distracted by my editors disgracefully walking over to talk about West Ham’s win over Arsenal on Saturday, Bautista Agut consolidates the break easily.

Updated at 9.19am GMT

9.09am GMT

Second set: Murray* 4-6, 2-3 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Bautista Agut is calm and focused and on the prowl when he moves into a 0-30 lead, with Murray looking increasingly stiff. These are worrying moments for Murray and netting a weary backhand at 15-30 gifts Bautista Agut two break points. The first one’s cancelled out with an ace. You fear for Murray in the extended duels, though. He tries a break point, but it’s got too much air on it, allowing Bautista Agut to race forward and pick Murray off at the net. There’s the break. The end is nigh. This is a decent effort from Murray given the circumstances, but you’re starting to see why he hasn’t got long left.

9.04am GMT

Second set: Murray 4-6, 2-2 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): A comfortable hold for Bautista Agut flashes by. “Greetings from a fraught sofa in Strathaven as me and the kids watch what seems increasingly likely to be Andy Murray’s last match,” James McNulty says. “My youngest (9) has just declared that ‘he can’t watch this any more’ and has flounced off to school. But hasn’t Murray always been hard to watch? Isn’t that - maybe uniquely among the top rank of British sportspeople - what makes him so totally compelling? The hip injury obviously make a critical difference - and this time he won’t be able shake it off. But over the years, the ebb and flow of emotion on-court and off it is what keeps us watching - right to the end. Honest, grumpy, tenacious, fragile and unflinchingly Scottish. We will miss him.”

9.00am GMT

Second set: Murray* 4-6, 2-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray strains and grimaces and clenches his fist after bashing a forehand from right to left for 30-0. He’s got a right to celebrate that one and he keeps moving with an ace for 40-0. Another one sees him hold to love.

8.58am GMT

Second set: Murray 4-6, 1-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): At 15-all, Murray comes up with a wondrous forehand return, rousing the crowd with a glorious angled shot from right to left. Bautista Agut’s left scrambling. This has come from nowhere - and Murray uses the adrenaline to win the next point, hitting an inside-out forehand down the line for two break points. He’s still got it, you know. His natural talent, however, is fighting a losing battle with his right hip and Bautista Agut wipes out both break points before holding on to his serve with more accurate hitting.

8.53am GMT

Second set: Murray* 4-6, 1-0 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray’s not going to give up easily. He comes through a tough game, holding to love. If he’s hurting, he’s hiding it well. “Completely agree with your views on Murray,” Matt Dony says. “The early snobbishness about him, the whole ‘Scottish if he loses’ schtick, the desire to see him as a plucky underdog (rather than someone who fought their way to the flipping Number 1 ranking!), the weirdly nasty fallout from that ‘Whoever’s playing England’ joke, people have used all manner of sticks to try and beat him with. But he’s played some magnificent tennis, he’s given some of the best, most insightful tennis press conferences I’ve ever seen, and (this can’t be overstated) he’s won multiple Grand Slams. He’s played in the same era as Federer, Djokovic and Rafa, and he’s proved himself alongside them. All while seeming genuinely down-to-Earth. If you don’t miss him when he’s gone, then you are, frankly, wrong.”

Updated at 9.03am GMT

8.47am GMT

Roberto Bautista Agut wins the first set 6-4!

Serving for the set, Bautista Agut makes it 15-0 with a cute volley. Murray walks to his chair. But only to get a new racket. He’s still fighting. But as much as he tries to hustle and scramble across the baseline, it just isn’t enough. Bautista Agut doesn’t take long to carve out three set points. In other news, Hawkeye has stopped working. The umpire has to phone a friend to find out if a Bautista Agut serve was out. It was - but it only delays the inevitable. Murray hits long and, as has so often been the case throughout his career, his he’s going to have to do this the hard way.

Updated at 8.58am GMT

8.41am GMT

First set: Murray* 4-5 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Having spurned a chance to break, the heat’s on Murray when he nets a forehand on the run to lose the first point of this crucial game. The tension builds as it goes to 30-all, though Murray does remember to congratulate Bautista Agut on a good crosscourt backhand. He has to admire the Spaniard’s level on the next point, too, with a well-judged backhand volley enough to earn Bautista Agut his first break point. Murray misses a first serve. Now he’s in a bit of a bind. Sure enough, Murray nets a forehand at the end of a lengthy rally. Bautista Agut will serve for the first set. Ah.

“Remember back in c. November 2016 when we were nearly convinced that Roger Federer was going to be the first member of the Big Four to retire?” Aditi Modi says. “Gut wrenching as that episode is going to be when it eventually does occur, Murray’s retirement is painful in its own way... Man, is he going to be missed.”

Updated at 8.49am GMT

8.34am GMT

First set: Murray 4-4 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Murray pumps his fists after seizing the initiative early in the rally, giving him the chance to punch a forehand past Bautista Agut for 15-all. You can tell he wants to use the atmosphere, to put on a bit of a show, to make the crowd get into his opponent’s head. There’s a sense it might be working when Bautista Agut, normally so accurate, drops a poor forehand long for 30-all. Murray’s firing himself up. He whips a forehand from right to left and earns a break point when Bautista Agut slices into the net. “Let’s go!” Murray roars. “No!” he cries after netting a backhand for deuce. How badly he wants this! But Bautista Agut isn’t going to just give it to him. He holds out after a tight backhand error from Murray.

Updated at 8.39am GMT

8.26am GMT

First set: Murray* 4-3 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Realising that he needs to be efficient, Murray doesn’t hesitate to wallop a forehand past Bautista Agut for 15-0. But he’s grunting and groaning during the next point, letting out a strained cry as Bautista Agut bashes a forehand down the line. Murray somehow gets it back, but Bautista Agut wins the point to make it 15-all. Those are the moments when you can sense the damage in his right hip. He’s battling away, though, and holds to 15.

Updated at 8.27am GMT

8.21am GMT

First set: Murray 3-3 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): At 30-15, Murray clips a lovely back from left to right and moves to the net, only to misjudge Bautista Agut’s clever backhand reply. Off balance, Murray sticks a disappointing backhand wide for 40-15. There are sighs. But the applause is louder when Murray rips a backhand down the line for 40-30. He’s in the game. The next rally’s along one. But it ends with Murray dragging a forehand wide. He isn’t convincing when Bautista Agut gets him moving from side to side.

8.17am GMT

First set: Murray* 3-2 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray’s forehand is showing signs of vulnerability, two tame errors handing Bautista Agut a 0-30 lead. His supporters try to rouse him. There’s relief when Bautista Agut drills an attempted winner wide, a challenge from the Spaniard confirming it was out. 15-30 rather than 0-40, then, allowing Murray to relax and serve well for 30-all. “Come on!” he cries, trying to gee himself up and get rid of the early nerves. Then he looks to quicken the pace, dropping in a bit of serve-volley, which hurries Bautista Agut into a wayward backhand for 40-30. Continuing with that approach sees Murray hold, much to the crowd’s approval. He’s got a spring in his step as he bounces back to his chair. There’s a long way to go, but he’s giving this all he’s got.

8.11am GMT

First set: Murray 2-2 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut is giving nothing away on serve. Murray tries a forehand lob but the Spaniard reads it and puts a smash away for 40-0. Murray responds by hitting his forehand with more venom and makes it 40-15. He continues with that tactic – but then he admonishes himself after sending one well past the baseline. The timing’s a little off.

8.06am GMT

First set: Murray* 2-1 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Murray’s having a bit of a chunter about something or other after moving into a 30-0 lead. Still as grumpy as ever. After a chat with the umpire about whatever’s bothering him, he whacks an ace down the middle for 40-0. He holds comfortably.

Updated at 8.07am GMT

8.03am GMT

First set: Murray 1-1 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): One of the challenges for Bautista Agut is to play the match rather than the occasion. It would be easy for him to be distracted by the carnival atmosphere. Yet he looks focused early on, easily moving into a 40-0 lead. Murray wastes a challenge after a backhand drifts just wide and Bautista Agut holds to love.

8.00am GMT

First set: Murray* 1-0 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): With cries of encouragement from the crowd ringing in his ears, Murray steps up to serve after winning the toss. The first point’s a long baseline grind, just like Bautista Agut likes it, just as Murray used to like it, and the Spaniard takes it when he watches a forehand sail long. The camera pans to Judy Murray, who’s got her poker face on. Back to the action. Murray wins the next point when Bautista Agut nets a return. Big roar. Then Murray fires an ace down the middle. Optimism soars. The game goes to 30-all, Bautista Agut spanking a forehand deep into the left corner, but Murray holds out with a couple of solid serves. He’ll be relieved to be on the board straight away.

7.55am GMT

Tok! Tok! Tok! They’re knocking up. Whatever happens over the next few hours, try to remember the good times with Andy Murray. Try to remember the time the balls fell out of his pocket during his match against Marcos Baghdatis at Wimbledon in 2012. Or the time he lost a point in a US Open semi-final because his cap fell off. Or all the swearing. In a list of great eccentric athletes, he’s up there. He isn’t the best tennis player of all time, but there haven’t been many with as interesting and beguiling a character as him.

7.52am GMT

But it feels like a tall order. Roberto Bautista Agut has started the year well. He’s a good mover, a solid hitter and he’ll be confident after his recent triumph in Doha, when he beat Novak Djokovic in the semis before seeing off Tomas Berdych to take the title.

7.50am GMT

Here come the players! Roberto Bautista Agut is the first to emerge. He gets a nice cheer but it’s nothing that compares to the roar that greets Andy Murray on Hisense Arena. There are plenty of Scots in the crowd. Plenty of Saltires lifted aloft on a sunny Melbourne evening. The stands are full to the brim. It’s going to be a great atmosphere. You just hope Murray has something left in the locker.

Updated at 8.05am GMT

7.48am GMT

Simon’s email gets me thinking about all these years I’ve spent watching Andy Murray. I like to think we have a connection because I’m only a couple of months older than him. In a way – IN. A. WAY. – we’ve grown up together. He’s famous, I’m ... not. He’s a millionaire, I’m ... not. We’re exactly alike! Honest. I even had a dream we were best mates once. Went to the pub and shot the breeze. My wife thought about leaving me when I told her.

Am I sharing too much? Maybe. But this is a nostalgic moment, isn’t it? I remember watching the teenage Murray when he took on David Nalbandian at Wimbledon in 2005. He faded after taking the first two sets – but what a talent! And he was back the next year, even stronger as he destroyed Andy Roddick. At that point you knew he was going to be special; he just needed a few things to come together.

It took a while, of course, and he had to go through plenty of setbacks before scratching that itch. There were times when you thought he might not make it, especially when he kept losing to The Other Three at the business end of grand slams.

But then we stayed up with him until the early hours when he won the US Open in 2012, two months after weeping on Centre Court following his defeat to Roger Federer in his first Wimbledon final. A year later he tortured us as he won that first Wimbledon title after outlasting Novak Djokovic in the heat.

There have been so many great moments. You can’t help but wish him well.

7.41am GMT

“As remarkable as they are, the bare statistics of Murray’s career don’t even begin to do him justice,” Simon McMahon says. “3 Grand Slams. 11 Grand Slam finals. World No. 1. Two Olympic golds. 14 Masters 1000. The Davis Cup. Favourite memories? The irresistible rise to World No. 1, when Murray seemed to win tournament after tournament, in what now appears to be his last great effort before his body finally gave out. Final point in Davis Cup final, when Murray collapsed on to the clay and was then swamped by teammates but still had the class to get up and commiserate with Goffin. Winning Wimbledon against Djokovic. Olympic final against Del Potro. Somehow beating Robredo in Valencia. The chuntering. Thank you Andy. A sad day, but remarkable memories of a glittering career. Britain’s greatest ever sportsman? I’d say he’s in the top one.”

7.40am GMT

7.35am GMT

Tomas Berdych beats Kyle Edmund 6-3, 6-0, 7-5!

A semi-finalist here last year, a first-round loser this time. A day to forget for Kyle Edmund after being comprehensively outplayed by a beaming Berdych, who’s rolled back the years with a performance that showed why he’s a former top 10 player and grand slam finalist. Berdych has gone deep in this tournament in the past, reaching the last four in 2015 (who beat him? You know who beat him), and the Czech will take a lot of positives from this win after his recent injury problems.

7.32am GMT

“Come on Jacob, Dan Evans has served his time, report his win!” Simon Parmenter says.

Whoops. You are correct. Dan Evans, having made it through qualifying, did indeed secure a very good win over Japan’s Taro Daniel earlier. A boost for British tennis! Which is just as well, because...

7.30am GMT

Hold that thought. A killer forehand down the line seals the crucial break for Tomas Berdych, who clenches his fist after stomping into a 6-5 lead in the third. The Czech will serve for it. Kyle Edmund’s on the brink.

7.28am GMT

Though he has a mountain to climb to reach the second round, Kyle Edmund is fighting hard in the third set on Hisense Arena. He had a set point when Berdych was serving at 4-5, but couldn’t take. It’s 5-5 now and Edmund has just saved a break point.

7.21am GMT

If you don’t get Andy Murray, we can’t be friends. Sorry. You can always judge someone’s character based on whether they like the Scot, who’s made himself more than a tennis player with his unapologetic feminism and lack of machismo.

Related: The unapologetic feminism that turned Andy Murray into a global icon | Jacob Steinberg

7.14am GMT

7.08am GMT

While we wait for Murray, who’s been spotted warming up with his team, why not read Nick Kyrgios on what it was like playing his friend?

Related: Nick Kyrgios: ‘I wasn’t as scared of Rafa and Roger as I was Andy Murray’

7.07am GMT

In better news for the Brits, though, at least Katie Boulter is through to the second round after beating the tough Russian Ekaterina Makarova in three sets. The 22-year-old has a difficult one coming up, though: she faces Aryna Sabalenka next.

7.04am GMT

Pre-match reading

Related: Australian Open 2019: Five to watch in the men’s draw | Jacob Steinberg

Related: Australian Open 2019: Five to watch in the women’s draw

7.04am GMT

Let’s hope this isn’t a sign of things to come for the Brits. Day one of the 2019 Australian Open hasn’t gone too well so far. Harriet Dart was thrashed 6-0, 6-0 by Maria Sharapova earlier and Heather Watsona also lost badly to Petra Martic. On the men’s side, meanwhile, British No1 Kyle Edmund is currently being whooped by Tomas Berdych, who leads 6-3, 6-0, 2-2 on Hisense Arena. Murray and Bautista Agut are next up on this court.

Related: Australian Open gets underway as Maria Sharapova dismisses Harriet Dart

5.37am GMT

Preamble

Hello. Maybe, just maybe, this is all building up to the unlikeliest of happy endings. Maybe, against all the odds, against all available logic and reason, this is going to be the start of a fairytale run for the wonderful Andy Murray. Over the next fortnight, maybe his body won’t conspire against him, allowing his best tennis to flourish. He’ll win match after match. Roger Federer is on his side of the draw, but he’ll beat the defending champion. He’ll keep winning in gutsy fashion, drawing on his and he’ll make it to his sixth Australian Open final. He’ll win his first Australian Open title, cry a bit on the podium – okay, cry a lot on the podium – announce his retirement from the sport knowing that he has nothing left to achieve and skip happily off into the sunset. Is that too much to ask?

Answer: probably. Sigh. Because, unfortunately, we all know that we could be about to watch Andy Murray’s final ever match. Hankies at the ready, everyone, because this could be emotional. Even if Murray knows there is more to life than tennis, this has all been desperately hard to take. He’s put us through the wringer on so many occasions in the past and he was at it again last week, revealing in a painful and poignant press conference that the hip injury that has dogged him for the past two years has simply become too much to handle. He says he can barely tie his shoelaces without feeling pain any more. He says he’ll see if he can make it to Wimbledon later this year. He knows that might not happen. He accepts he’s likely to lose this first-round match to Roberto Bautista Agut, the 22nd seed. He knows this particular journey is approaching its final destination with unforgiving speed.

The weirdness here is that the thought of Bautista Agut beating peak Murray is pretty laughable. Even Bautista Agut’s nearest and dearest know that. Murray leads his head-to-head with the Spaniard 3-0 and two years ago he arrived at this tournament as the world No1, having overtaken Novak Djokovic and risen to the top of the tree after a magnificent end to 2016. He seemed poised for a long rule; little did we know. The decline has been sharp, rapid and cruel, and it has left Murray physically and spiritually shattered. Even for as someone as stubborn and tough as the former three-time grand slam champion, Davis Cup winner and double Olympic gold medalist, this still feels like a long shot.

Then again, it is Andy Murray. Let’s not rule out the preposterous yet.
fields.bodyText: Anyway, that’s all from me. We’ve been treated to an Andy Murray classic, a see-sawing five-setter which has been utterly draining to watch. If this was his final match, he’s bowed out in style. It ended in defeat to Roberto Bautista Agut, but this was the ultimate moral victory for Murray. Thanks for reading and emailing. Bye. You’ll probably want to know that Roger Federer has beaten Denis Istomin in straight sets, while Bernard Tomic is out after losing to Marin Cilic. Rafael Nadal also sailed through after beating Australia’s James Duckworth. Caroline Wozniacki, the defending women’s champion, is also through to the second round. That’s all from Andy Murray. Now he gets to drag himself off for an ice bath. You know, it’s probably for the best he doesn’t have to play on Wednesday. He looked in agony by the end. Four hours and nine minutes that took. What now? The likelihood is that was Murray’s final match. He’s hinting at having an operation to deal with his chronic right hip. He’d love to play one more match at Wimbledon, which would be a fitting venue for his farewell. But how much more can he take? More from Murray! “I’ve been very fortunate in mny ways - and unlucky, I guess - to compete in an era with the guys around. Roger, Novak, Rafa, I have great respect for them. I’ve had some great battles. To have the respect of your peers is very important.” Now we’ve heard from Andy Murray, he gets to look up the big screen, where they’re showing a montage of tributes from his colleagues. “You’ve done Scotland proud, you’ve done Britain proud, you’re a sir - who can say that?”Roger Federer says. Over to Novak Djokovic, who remembers the time Murray “kicked my butt” at Wimbledon in 2013. “Thank you always for leaving your heart and every last drop of energy on the court,” the world No1 adds. “Judy raised such a fine young gentleman,” Sloane Stephens says. Caroline Wozniacki says she can coach him. “Take care, buddy,” Federer says. “Thank you, my friend,” Djokovic adds. “All the best.” Andy Murray, his voice wobbling and his bottom lip trembling, speaks! “Amazing. I think I’m going to be all right. Thank you so much to everyone who came out tonight. I’ve loved playing here over the years. If this was the last match it was an amazing way to end. I gave literally everything I had. It wasn’t enough tonight, so congratulations to Roberto and his team. I don’t really have anything else to say. Thanks to everyone. My team, my family, everyone who helped me down the years. Maybe I’ll see you again. I’ll do everything possible to try. If I want to go again I need to have a big operation which there’s no guarantee I’ll come back from but I’ll give it my best shot. Roberto Bautista Agut, who plays Australia’s John Millman next, speaks! “Today was incredible. Andy deserves this atmosphere. Andy deserves all the people who came to watch him. It was an unbelievable match. He is a tough fighter. He gave everything he had until the last point and I want to congratulate him for everything he did for tennis.” Andy Murray’s off his chair to accept the crowd’s acclaim. Nobody’s going anywhere. Judy’s managing to smile as she watches her brilliant son. This, then, could be the final game of Sir Andy Murray’s career. Here we are. We don’t want to be here. But here we are. It’s been one hell of a ride, but the finishing line is hovering into view, with Bautista Agut quick to establish a 30-0 lead. Murray being Murray, he continues to scramble, drawing on those unrivalled retrieval skills, but it’s not enough any more. Bautista Agut softens up his prey before earning three match points with a smash. He wallops a forehand down the line. Murray gets a racket to it - of course he does - but it’s not going over the net. It’s over. Bautista Agut roars and the pair embrace at the net. There were two winners out there today. Fifth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 2-5 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): After four hours of sweat, huge applause greets Murray as he steps up to serve. He looks like he has something in his eye. They’re a little red. Judy looks emotional. Murray holds his racket high to signal his appreciation for a tremendous ovation. Then he gets down to business, winning the first point. The camera pans back to Judy, who’s just about managing to hold it together. Just. Murray, determined not to let the moment pass, nails an ace for 30-15. Back to Judy. Frowning. Jamie Murray, Andy’s big brother, also looks fretful. Bautista Agut wins the next point thanks to a lucky net cord. Then a huge return from the Spaniard causes Murray to net a tired forehand. It’s the first match point. Murray being Murray, though, he keeps running, keeps hustling, keeps pouring his soul into all he does, and he saves it with a brilliant volley. Judy’s smiling now. Somehow Murray holds, serving superbly. One more clenched fist. A small victory for Murray but it looks like it means the world to him. Bautista Agut will serve for it. He’s going to win this match, surely, but he hasn’t managed to crush Murray’s spirit. Fifth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-5 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): Bautista Agut holds to love. He’s a game from victory. Murray will serve to stay in it. It is likely to be his last ever service game at the Australian Open, a tournament he love so much. Fifth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-4 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): Fuel’s leaking all over the place now. From 30-0, Murray dips again and Bautista Agut fights back to earn a break point. Murray nets a backhand. He looks cooked. There’s surely no way back now. Fifth set: Murray 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-3 Bautista Agut* (*denotes server): A love hold consolidates the break for Bautista Agut. Are we witnessing the end for Murray? Or is there another twist on the way? Fifth set: Murray* 4-6, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, 1-2 Bautista Agut (*denotes server): It’s worth remembering that this will go to a champion’s tie-break if it goes to 6-6; it would be first to 10 points in that scenario. But it might not get that far. At 15-30, Murray makes a couple of questionable choices. A drop shot isn’t good enough and a hopeful lob’s gobbled up by Bautista Agut, who finds himself with two break points. It took a while, of course, and he had to go through plenty of setbacks before scratching that itch. There were times when you thought he might not make it, especially when he kept losing to The Other Three at the business end of grand slams. But then we stayed up with him until the early hours when he won the US Open in 2012, two months after weeping on Centre Court following his defeat to Roger Federer in his first Wimbledon final. A year later he tortured us as he won that first Wimbledon title after outlasting Novak Djokovic in the heat. There have been so many great moments. You can’t help but wish him well. “As remarkable as they are, the bare statistics of Murray’s career don’t even begin to do him justice,” Simon McMahon says. “3 Grand Slams. 11 Grand Slam finals. World No. 1. Two Olympic golds. 14 Masters 1000. The Davis Cup. Favourite memories? The irresistible rise to World No. 1, when Murray seemed to win tournament after tournament, in what now appears to be his last great effort before his body finally gave out. Final point in Davis Cup final, when Murray collapsed on to the clay and was then swamped by teammates but still had the class to get up and commiserate with Goffin. Winning Wimbledon against Djokovic. Olympic final against Del Potro. Somehow beating Robredo in Valencia. The chuntering. Thank you Andy. A sad day, but remarkable memories of a glittering career. Britain’s greatest ever sportsman? I’d say he’s in the top one.” A semi-finalist here last year, a first-round loser this time. A day to forget for Kyle Edmund after being comprehensively outplayed by a beaming Berdych, who’s rolled back the years with a performance that showed why he’s a former top 10 player and grand slam finalist. Berdych has gone deep in this tournament in the past, reaching the last four in 2015 (who beat him? You know who beat him), and the Czech will take a lot of positives from this win after his recent injury problems. “Come on Jacob, Dan Evans has served his time, report his win!” Simon Parmenter says. Whoops. You are correct. Dan Evans, having made it through qualifying, did indeed secure a very good win over Japan’s Taro Daniel earlier. A boost for British tennis! Which is just as well, because... Hold that thought. A killer forehand down the line seals the crucial break for Tomas Berdych, who clenches his fist after stomping into a 6-5 lead in the third. The Czech will serve for it. Kyle Edmund’s on the brink. Though he has a mountain to climb to reach the second round, Kyle Edmund is fighting hard in the third set on Hisense Arena. He had a set point when Berdych was serving at 4-5, but couldn’t take. It’s 5-5 now and Edmund has just saved a break point. If you don’t get Andy Murray, we can’t be friends. Sorry. You can always judge someone’s character based on whether they like the Scot, who’s made himself more than a tennis player with his unapologetic feminism and lack of machismo. While we wait for Murray, who’s been spotted warming up with his team, why not read Nick Kyrgios on what it was like playing his friend? In better news for the Brits, though, at least Katie Boulter is through to the second round after beating the tough Russian Ekaterina Makarova in three sets. The 22-year-old has a difficult one coming up, though: she faces Aryna Sabalenka next. Pre-match reading Let’s hope this isn’t a sign of things to come for the Brits. Day one of the 2019 Australian Open hasn’t gone too well so far. Harriet Dart was thrashed 6-0, 6-0 by Maria Sharapova earlier and Heather Watsona also lost badly to Petra Martic. On the men’s side, meanwhile, British No1 Kyle Edmund is currently being whooped by Tomas Berdych, who leads 6-3, 6-0, 2-2 on Hisense Arena. Murray and Bautista Agut are next up on this court. Hello. Maybe, just maybe, this is all building up to the unlikeliest of happy endings. Maybe, against all the odds, against all available logic and reason, this is going to be the start of a fairytale run for the wonderful Andy Murray. Over the next fortnight, maybe his body won’t conspire against him, allowing his best tennis to flourish. He’ll win match after match. Roger Federer is on his side of the draw, but he’ll beat the defending champion. He’ll keep winning in gutsy fashion, drawing on his and he’ll make it to his sixth Australian Open final. He’ll win his first Australian Open title, cry a bit on the podium – okay, cry a lot on the podium – announce his retirement from the sport knowing that he has nothing left to achieve and skip happily off into the sunset. Is that too much to ask? Answer: probably. Sigh. Because, unfortunately, we all know that we could be about to watch Andy Murray’s final ever match. Hankies at the ready, everyone, because this could be emotional. Even if Murray knows there is more to life than tennis, this has all been desperately hard to take. He’s put us through the wringer on so many occasions in the past and he was at it again last week, revealing in a painful and poignant press conference that the hip injury that has dogged him for the past two years has simply become too much to handle. He says he can barely tie his shoelaces without feeling pain any more. He says he’ll see if he can make it to Wimbledon later this year. He knows that might not happen. He accepts he’s likely to lose this first-round match to Roberto Bautista Agut, the 22nd seed. He knows this particular journey is approaching its final destination with unforgiving speed. The weirdness here is that the thought of Bautista Agut beating peak Murray is pretty laughable. Even Bautista Agut’s nearest and dearest know that. Murray leads his head-to-head with the Spaniard 3-0 and two years ago he arrived at this tournament as the world No1, having overtaken Novak Djokovic and risen to the top of the tree after a magnificent end to 2016. He seemed poised for a long rule; little did we know. The decline has been sharp, rapid and cruel, and it has left Murray physically and spiritually shattered. Even for as someone as stubborn and tough as the former three-time grand slam champion, Davis Cup winner and double Olympic gold medalist, this still feels like a long shot. Then again, it is Andy Murray. Let’s not rule out the preposterous yet.

webTitle: Poem of the week: Why the swan by Andrew Lambeth

fields.headline: Poem of the week: Why the swan by Andrew Lambeth
fields.standfirst: The writer discovers in this familiar but enigmatic creature an elusive emblem
fields.trailText: The writer discovers in this familiar but enigmatic creature an elusive emblem
fields.body:
Why the swan

Because the swan floats
up close.

Because the swan has no life
off past the cut-off.

Because the swan is a knife
turned in on itself.

Because the swan erases
unwhite surfaces.

Because the swan is a sign of
what to expect, like a specked cough.

Because the swan isn’t
drawn like an ear. It listens

but it won’t hear, won’t look
up in time. It’s as if it’s stuck.

Because the air shushes sirens,
because the canal divulges silence,

because the curves have been stolen
from what’s left of the swan,

which is its song, of course –
the long stretch between locks.

The author of this week’s poem will be known to many readers of this series as the enigmatically named commenter nosuchzone. Largely spared a formal education, and entirely innocent of the university Eng Lit or creative writing courses, Andrew Lambeth is a typographer and editor, still comparatively new to writing poetry. Regulars of this blog will already know how good and original a poet he is from the distinctive work he posts below the line. Publication is not a priority for him, but it’s still good to see that his work is beginning to be more widely recognised. Recently, for example, he was published by Helen Mort and Stuart Maconie in their anthology of pub-related poetry, One for the Road.

It’s surprising, at first glance, to find him writing about a swan. Swans, after all, are the most literary of birds. A substantial and high-quality swan-poem anthology would begin with Orlando Gibbons and welcome into its pages, among others, WB Yeats, Sara Teasdale, Stevie Smith and Baudelaire with his almost unbearably tragic Le Cygne. These poetic swans are variously symbolic: in Teasdale’s verses, for example, they are a silent chorus, an unspoken erotic commentary. Swans aren’t always associated with grief and death, an association born of the once widely held but baseless notion that they sing only when about to die. The Greek legend in which Apollo’s soul becomes a swan may be more significant; write about a swan, and you’re inevitably writing about high art. Whatever they symbolise, poetry’s swans are rarely non-iconic. As in real life, a swan is a powerful, ambivalent presence, both coarse and ethereal, with a neck like a weaponised question mark.

Lambeth’s title, Why the swan, could be interpreted as a question, possibly about the swan’s status as poetic material, with the ensuing couplets (all of which, apart from the last, start with “Because”) forming a list of unpredictable answers. The poem may want to explain each time, “this is why swans are supercharged visual and literary emblems” and perhaps, also, explain why they shouldn’t be so stereotyped. But it also seems, at least sometimes, that the poem is asking plaintively why this particular swan has been singled out, not for poetry, but for abuse. Early on, the truncated-seeming lines, with their unexpected breaks and unsettling para-rhyme, intimate mortality: “the swan has no life / off past the cut-off”, it “is a knife/ turned in on itself.” Stanza four glances aside, in homage to immaculate whiteness. But the death-resonance sounds increasingly as the poem develops. The swan becomes an ominous sign, “like a specked cough” (note the spitty alliteration of “expect” and “specked”). It’s hard at this point not to think of the terminally sick, expectorating Keats. The figure of the tubercular poet, like the swan, attracts false romanticism.

Readers of Strix will have the advantage of comparing Why the swan with the neighbouring poem, Towpath (tinnitus). The latter, earthier and more subjective, focuses on a “strange singing” that wrests the poet’s descriptive powers into inventive analogy. The sound is “Like singing / backwards. Like whistling inside croaking” and later becomes “a whistle stretched / to a fine scream”. There’s no swan on the canal in this poem, although other birds are noted, but perhaps it’s the unnerving, unidentifiable (and possibly internally produced) singing heard in Towpath (tinnitus) that forms the background music, and the impetus, of Why the swan.

The poet’s visually trained eye brilliantly connect the bird’s shape with listening and hearing. When the swan sleeps, with its head buried in the feathers of its back, the outline resembles that of a large ear. But the resemblance involves simultaneous denial. This particular swan or its image “isn’t / drawn like an ear”, a statement underlining the bird’s essential distance from the human species, and possibly the pathos of superhuman sensory awareness combined with the inability to interpret the noise of threat.

Offstage, out of the picture, some seeming drama occurs. “It … won’t look up in time. It’s as if it’s stuck.” Stanzas eight and nine begin with the ominous noise of sirens and their “shushing” and silencing by collusive air, and end with the drab rawness of “what’s left of the swan”.

The final couplet defines “what’s left” not as physical remains, but as “song”. This isn’t a comfortingly aesthetic return to tradition: the song is equated with something mundane and industrial, “the long stretch between locks”. That “long stretch” may consist of the canal’s water, the towpath, or life itself; the “locks” may be the kind that enable passage, or frustrate it. The phrase reminds us of the Orlando Gibbons lyrics, in which death has “unlocked” the swan’s throat. Inevitably, “stretched” suggests Baudelaire’s caged swan, escaped and lost in a Parisian street, desperately straining its neck towards the sky.

Lambeth’s poem, as the bird’s latest wounded incarnation, earns an honourable place in the later pages of our swan anthology, as an elusive emblem appropriate to the place and time.

• Why the swan is one of the two poems by Andrew Lambeth published in Issue #5 of Strix.
